course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Inorganic Chemistry II
course.description: Mechanism of inorganic reactions, organometallic and bioinorganic chemistry, catalysis.

reviews.author: cyc_yin
reviews.comment_content: 首先背野要下苦功，通常記唔少structures同各種inorg compounds既特性、formula等，不過重點要學既都會特別講。你睇下背下就會容易理解佢教個套model既規則，之後apply落d問題度就解到。另外會講唔少inorg compound既applications，係midterm同final既特別送分位，考你有無聽書同背書。
reviews.comment_teaching: 華雄梗係好啦，有本地prof仲想點呀。佢好樂意解答問題，用廣東話解實易明。可以問埋TA，因為華雄lab既TA多本地人，易D明。
reviews.comment_grading: 只要有背書，配合埋你理解左既model個套理論，A range在望，唔係坊間所講既萬人之「C」咁樣爛grade。
reviews.comment_workload: 平時堂堂有PRS take attendance，答岩就多D分，不過PRS最終評分最多都係1分。另外好似基本Chem course咁樣，兩份assignments分別mt 同final前交，仲有兩個全MC既quiz，佔好少之餘順便幫你溫書。不過mt 同final題目都幾多，要做快D。

reviews.author: ilubyouboyz
reviews.title: Prof. Leung is a responsible instructor!
reviews.comment_content:
Unit 1 - Coordination chemistry (easiest part of the course)
Unit 2 - Organometallic chemistry (hardest part, there were reactions to remember and to apply :') , yet still easier than organic chem ones)
Unit 3 - Main group chemistry
reviews.comment_teaching:
I highly appreciate the adequate numbers of exercises and tutorials for us to revise before assessments! I think this was the reason that I got quite satisfactory marks (at least for me they were satisfactory).

Prof. Leung held office hours throughout the semester but seemed just few of us went to ask him questions. But I know there are quite a number of us asked him questions through email, and I did too. He was responding to my emails very efficiently and clearly. By the way, office hours were optional. For the attendance of tutorials, it is optional but will be critical when your marks are on the boundaries of the letter grades. So please consider to join actively and discipline yourselves.

The lectures were quite rush, but Prof. Leung was willing to stop and answer questions whenever we expressed that we didn't understand a certain part or wanted to know some more extensive knowledge. The lecture notes were clear enough. He provided a summary for each units too, they were so useful. He is a passionate teacher!
reviews.comment_grading:
Just as normal chem courses. Reasonable.
4% x 2 Assignments: (my mark, mean / total marks)
1 - 31.5, 24.6/34
2 - 23.5, 18.6/30

18% x 3 Quizzes:
1 - 18, 13.6/20
2 - 14.5, 13.0/24
3 - 16.5, 15.5/24

32% Final exam:
Paper 1 - 20.5, 16.6/24
Paper 2 - 13.5, 13.7/32

6% Others (iPRS. participation) - Not revealed.

Overall grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
A normal 3 credit course workload, so don't worry. Spend your time according to the percentage of weighting on each assessment will be totally fine!

3 quizzes: each of them were held right after a unit is finished.
2 assignments: first one was before quiz 1, second one was after quiz 2.
Final exam: paper 1 was like the 4th quiz, it tested about the very last bits of unit 3; paper 2 required some drawings and short answers.
Participation: make sure you attend lesson, if you turn on camera it will be even better.

reviews.comment_content:
Coordination Chemistry
Organometallic chemistry of transition elements

教得唔差 肯解釋問題
midterm final嘅問題同上堂學嘅差好遠
Long question基本上好難答得到

mid term below mean半個SD

最後C-咗

Assignments (2)

reviews.author: RichardY
reviews.comment_content: Content is very well designed in my opinion (I feel that I had learnt a lot). Content covers mostly transition elements and organometallic chemistry (both transition and main group organometallics). Various explanations on observed properties and phenomena are sought via concepts related to crystal field theory, MO, thermodynamics and kinetics. Notable topics include catalytic mechanism of transition metal catalyst and syntheses/reactions of a wide variety of compounds explained in terms of various theory (These are the topics that make me feel that I finally can do things which a chemist is supposed to be capable of).
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good teacher indeed. There is really not a single thing I can nitpick him.
reviews.comment_grading: Overall ~ 95% (class overall mean ~ 70%) got an A+. I do not know much about what other people got but the grade should be pretty good as long as Prof. Leung is the instructor.
reviews.comment_workload: Two assignments, two quizzes, two exams. Workload is slightly smaller than inorganic chem I. For me, the time spent to study inorg II was less than inorg I but I am still able to maintain at a high level. The reason is that the content of inorg II rest on the foundation knowledge learnt in inorg I (which I have done pretty good) whereas you mostly start from scratch in inorg I. It seems there is more memorization judging from the content but I think the exams actually test your understanding rather than plain memorization.

reviews.author: hww
reviews.comment_content:
主要分3大part
第一part係教coordination chemistry
part II 教organometallic chemistry
part III 教main group chemistry
每一part都有關聯
其實內容唔太難，比起Inorg I 易10倍
認真聽書既話其實唔難
reviews.comment_teaching:
香港PROF，chem dept黎講無乜邊個
教得幾好，專講考試位
成個course都似exam-oriented，3次tutor,好多份problem set比你慢慢操
reviews.comment_grading:
2 quiz 4% each
2 assignment 3% each
prs 3%
mt 37%
final 46%
mt 同final above 個幾sd A+左

reviews.author: Laiiiii
reviews.title: Quite good
reviews.comment_content:
Coordination Chemistry
-Crystal Field Theory
-LFSE, HS/LS configuration
-Square Planar vs Tetrahedral Geometry
-Spectral, Magnetic and thermochemical Properties
-MO diagrams for coordination compounds

Organometallic Chemistry

Main Group Chemistry

He is nice.
Speaks a bit fast.

Finall Exam (Section A: MC and short questions)(Section B: Long Questions)

Overall a little bit heavy, many contents.
Work hard will be B range

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Leung
He teaches the 1st half of the course and he expliains the concepts in detail and I think he is one of the best professors among the courses I have taken. The tutorials given is good and the concepts are explained clearly.

Prof Quan
Prof Quan take over the course after midterm, start teaching from 2nd half of cycloolefin complexes. At first I think he is ok, but starting from the part of Main Group Chemistry, it is totally a disaster and I do not understand over 95% of the concepts he taught. The tutorials are also somehow messy and I have skipped the tutorials given by him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz (3x6%)
Assignments (2x5%)
Midterm (25%) (Cover up to cycloolefin complex)
Final Exam (45%) (Cover the contents after Midterm)
Polling (2%)

Midterm Exam (Consist of Short questions)
Finall Exam (Section A: MCQ and short questions)
                    (Section B: Long Questions)

Similar to CHEM2210
Both Exam and quizzes are open book
Final Grade C+, although most items below mean
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate I would say, similar to that of CHEM2210, only difference is most conceps before Midterm is simpier than that of CHEM2210 and open book exams.

reviews.author: 哈爾請食半島
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
This course divides 3 parts:
1. Coordination Chemistry
L1: Introduction
L2: Crystal Field Theory
L3: LFSE, LS/HS configuration, sq. planar vs tetrahedral geometry
L4: Spectral, magnetic and thermochemical properties
L5: MO diagram
L6: Coordination equilibria, chelate effect, Jahn-Teller effect

2. Organometallic Chemistry
L7: The 18-electron rule
L8: Metal carbonyl complexes
L9: Olefin and cycloolefin complexes
L10: Organometallic Reactions and Homogeneous Catalysis

3. Main Group Chemistry
L11: Main group hydrides
L12: Main group organometallic compounds
L13: Multiple Bonds Between Main group elements
L14: Inorganic Rings, Chains, and Cages

Mid-term: L1-L9 covered
Final: L9 (A little bit), L10-14 covered
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Leung and Prof Quan are good. They are willing for students to understand the concepts in CHEM3220 so they mention all the hand-outs detailly with some extra questions and polling. Also, they provide 7 problem sets and 4 tutorial exercises to consolidate the concepts very well and well prepare for your mid-term and final exams.
Some questions are similar to mid-term and final exams. (Ofc not the same. It changes the question sets with the same concepts. If you understand it, you can solve it). In addition, you can make appointments with two professors, and they are happy to help you.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
Quiz : 3x 6%
Assignment : 2x 6%
Mid-term: 20%
Final Exam: 48%
Other (polling, answer the question.....): 2%

Marks:
Quiz 1 :
My mark : 12/15 Mean: 10.1/15
High: 15 Low: 4

Quiz 2 :
My mark : 13/14 Mean: 9.6/14
High: 14 Low: 3

Quiz 3 :
My mark : 11/15 Mean: 7.9/15
High: 13 Low: 1

Assignment 1
My mark: 33.5/35 Mean: 30.9/35
High: 82 (I think it is an error in canvas) Low: 0

Assignment 2 :
My mark : 27/30 Mean: 21.9/30
High: 30 Low: 0

Mid-term:
My mark : 22/26 Mean: 17.1/26
High: 26  Low: 3

Final Exam
Section A (MC + Short Question related to 18-electron rule and O.S)
My mark: 20/30 Mean: 18.8/30
High: 28  Low: 8

Section B (Long Q) 13 question + 1 bonus question :
My mark : 35.5/51 Mean: 31.9/51
High: 46  Low: 8

Total: 55.5/81 Mean: 50.7/81

Others : not release

Overall grade: B+ (Before releasing the grade, I expect only B)
reviews.comment_workload:
I think it is quite a heavy workload if you want to desire a better grade.
Coordination Chemistry is fucking EZ so the mean of quiz 1 is quite high. You need to pay more attention to your careless mistake in the calculation.

I think the most challenging part is organometallic catalysis and the main group chem. You need to remember all of the key reaction steps in the catalysis cycle and characteristics in the main group chem (close to remembering of the content of L10-14). Although it is the open-notes exam, you need to remember the content of the notes if you want to get a better grade. Hence, in quiz 3, mainly focusing on the final part, the mean is quite low.

Mid-term is quite straight forward and you can answer it.
(Plz do problem sets, tutorial and review your assignment question)

The final Exam is normal (not easy but not difficult). I think the professor wants to divide some outstanding and normal students so some questions are very challenging in MC and Long Q. In the final exam, I don’t have enough time to do all the questions in section B. So, if you want to get an A range, try to understand all of the concepts in lecture notes. Good luck!

For others part, two professors encourage students to answer questions. You can get the marks if u do polling in zoom and tutorial sections. Because of I do all the polling in the lectures and attain all the tutorial sections after sometimes answer the questions. Therefore, I get the B+ rather than B. Sometimes this part can determines the grade. If you are not outstanding students and want to get higher grade, I highly suggest you answer the questions actively.

Overall, the course is good. You can desire a better grade if you work hard. B+ is very good to me.

reviews.author: phyllissssss
reviews.title: Wa Hung哥世一!!!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Inorganic chemistry II is mainly about coordination chemistry, the introduction of organometallic chemistry, and main group chemistry. The content is much simpler than inorganic chemistry I and is more interesting. But you need to spend some time to understand, remember, and practice.

Course Contents
1.Coordination ChemistryCrystal field theorySpectral, magnetic, and thermochemical properties, Coordination equilibria, chelate effect

2.Organometallic chemistry, The 18-electron rule Carbonyl and alkene compoundsOrganometallic reactions, homogeneous catalysis

3.Main group chemistryHydride and alkyl compounds, Element-element multiple bonds, Inorganic rings, and cages
reviews.comment_teaching:
In one sentence, maybe he is the best professor in the HKUST chemistry department.

He is nice, responsible, and good at explaining the concept. He also provides additional tutorials and problem sets to help us.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes (3)                               3x18%
Assignments (2)                       2x4%
Final exam                               32%
Others (iPRS, participation)     6%

There are no mt but three quizzes instead. Thus the pressure of final exam is much smaller. Questions are all quite easy and straightforward. And open-book makes you not necessary to remember everything. There are even some original questions (exactly the same) in your hw or additional practice or tutorials.
For me, almost full marks in every marking section, except for final paper 2, which is very hard and not able to complete. I only got 22/32 (mean about 13) for that part. To be honest, the TAs and instructor gave me higher scores than I expected. I think the grading scheme is quite decent. I heard last year the final and quizzes are quite easy and the mean is high. Lots of people last year got quite high scores (like more than 95% but not A+)  So I think this year the instructor has adjusted the difficulty and the mean is lower than last year. This year the instructor was likely to give more A+ since I got A+ eventually with overall about 93%, which is beyond my expectation.

上堂聽得明就唔洗花太多空餘時間溫。
Quiz/Assignments前比啲心機同時間溫/做，有6份problem sets，3個tutorial，唔識做到識為止。今個semester online上，3個quiz/Assignments 各自cover 3個大topic，final quiz就全部topic包曬。

reviews.author: LukaModric
reviews.comment_content:
(1) Coordination Chemistry
Classification of ligands, naming of inorganic complexes Crystal field theory: d-orbital splitting for octahedral, tetrahedral, tetragonal and square planar complexes
Factors that affect the size of crystal field splitting, spectrochemical series
High-spin and low-spin electron configurations, ligand field stabilization energies
Geometry of d8 complexes: square planar versus tetrahedral geometry
Spectral properties of metal ions: d-d and charge-transfer transitions
Magnetic properties of transition metal ions
Correlation of enthalpies of hydration of metal ions and lattice enthalpies of metal oxides with ligand field stabilization energies
Coordination equilibria, stepwise and overall formation constants, Irving-Williams series
Chelate and macrocyclic effects, applications of chelate ligands
Jahn-Teller distortion of Cu(II) compounds
Molecular orbital energy level diagrams of metal complexes, comparison of MO theory with crystal field theory

(2) Organometallic chemistry of transition elements
The 18-electron rule: rationale, examples, and exceptions
Electron count: ionic and covalent models
Carbonyl compounds: bonding and structures, factors affecting IR C-O stretching frequencies of metal carbonyls, synthesis and reactions of metal carbonyls, acidity of metal carbonyl hydride compounds
Ligands that are isoelectronic with CO (NO+, CN-, N2)
-----MIDTERM-----
Alkene and alkyne compounds
Organometallic reactions: oxidative addition, reductive elimination, and migratory insertion
Homogeneous catalysis: catalytic cycles for Rh-catalyzed alkene hydrogenation, Cocatalyzed alkene hydroformylation, metal-catalyzed polymerization of alkenes
Selectivity of catalytic reactions, Tolman cone angles of phosphines

(3) Main group hydride compounds
Classification of hydride compounds: saline, covalent, and metallic hydrides
Electron-deficient, electron-precise and electron-rich hydrides: bonding, structures, and stability, acid-base properties
Synthesis and reactions of hydride compounds

(4) Main group alkyl/aryl compounds
Thermodynamic and kinetic stabilities of metal alkyl compounds
Trends of M-C bond energies for transition and main group alkyl compounds
Bonding and structures of main group alkyl compounds
Inert pair effects
Synthesis and reactions of main group alkyl compounds    

(5) Element-element multiple bonds
Trends of element-element sigma and pi bonds
N2 vs. P4, O2 vs. S8
Multiple bonds between heavier elements, bonding and structure of Sn2R4
dpi-ppi interactions in R3Si-O-SiR3 and R3P=O

(6) Inorganic rings and cages
Inorganic rings: borazine, polysiloxane, phosphazenes
Inorganic cages
Boranes and carboranes: closo, nido and arachno polyhedra, Wades rules
Zintl ions
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Leung teaches quite fast and you only got one minute to answer an iPRS question. 3-4 iPRS questions per lecture.
iPRS will not be counted to the grades for now.
Prof. Leung teaches very clearly compared to other CHEM courses.
In the first 10mins of each lecture, he will summarize things covered in last lecture and things to be discussed in the recent lecture.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavier than other CHEM course as there are quizzes.
For the midterm, not much reactions to remember.
(If interested, CHEM 4620 can help you understand the organometallic chemistry part)
Prof. Jia will give an introduction at the beginning of the course. Afterward, you will find there are quite a lot of the same materials covered by both courses when CHEM 3220 begins to talk about organometallic chemistry. (Of coz CHEM 4620 will be more in deep but already helps you to understand those in CHEM 3220)
For the final, it seems the main group chemistry is a big guy.

reviews.author: stupidching
reviews.title: good and simple
reviews.comment_content: This is the same as others described
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor makes things clear and simplified so we are able to learn about some basic ideas of inorganic chemistry. He is willing to answer questions.I would remind everyone to listen to the lecture videos carefully.Sufficient practice is provided for high grades. Thorough understanding still require higher level courses.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading was very good because one of my friends got around 80% but this turned out to be a A.
I got around 105% in total because professor likes to deduct the base mark. For example, you get 80/80 in the final exam but he thinks the paper may be difficult so he will make the full mark to be 78.Therefore, someone will get 80/78.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not that high.
Two assignments
Two quizzes
One midterm and one final
Some iPRS

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.comment_content:
A course of memorization and regurgitation of information.

You would learn what pi-donors (weak-field ligands), pi-acceptors (strong-field ligands) and sigma donors are; how to determine a transition metal complex's stability by calculating its splitting energy and hence its structure (tetrahedral? square planar? octahedral?);

how jahn-teller effect distorts a complex and affects its d-orbitals' splitting; organometallics (cyclo???enyl ligands);

how catalysts work (oxidative addition, reductive elimination, migratory insertion, cross-coupling);

main group elements; physical & chemical properties with respect to their kinetic/thermodynamic stability (poor orbital overlap? bond strength? vacant d-orbital? 2/3p-2/3p interaction? 2p pi-3d pi interaction?);

3-centre-2-electron-bond (B2H6) < 3-centre-4-electron bond ((AlCl3)2 etc.);

in what forms molecules of different main group elements would exist (dimer? polymer? covalent structure? ionic structure?)......

Too many things to recite. I can't remember all and do not bother to chase them out from my former course list hidden on Canvas to save leisure time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
One of the best professors I have ever seen. Even though the teaching pace is sometimes too fast, it's still very clear and comprehensible. He is really eager to dispel any doubt you have and fairly friendly to us.  

So many iPRS questions during lessons to test your understanding, asked halfway every chapter, before recess and when every lesson ends.
reviews.comment_grading: I fell below mean for a few marks in both mid-term and final. As expected, C+......Nothing to hope in this respect at UST.
reviews.comment_workload:
Two assignments, like 5% each, covering typical questions in the exams. Exams' ones are harder.

Two Quizzes, before mid-term and end of term respectively. 14 MCs each. Forgot the exact % they take up.
